Context:
This program is a two-year construction technology diploma offered at George Brown College in Ontario, Canada. The program covers practical applications in residential construction and renovations, millwork, demolition, framing, finishes, drywall installation and finishing, site management, cabinetry, stair construction, building code, basic electrical systems, HVAC systems, and plumbing systems.

Business skills taught include business management, marketing, client relations, project management, site management, scheduling, controlling, estimating and bookkeeping, budgeting and financial management, and inspections. Students will also learn how to use computer software and technology commonly used in the construction industry.

The program consists of four semesters. Semester 1 includes courses such as Residential Construction Lab 1, Plan Interpretation 1, History of Architecture, Communicating Across Contexts, Mathematics for Building Technologies 1, and Construction Safety & Rig. Students are required to complete two semesters of field placement as part of the program.

Graduates may be eligible for direct entry into the third year of George Brown College's Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) degree program with bridge courses required. For more information, see the Diploma to Degree page on the college website.

Students who start the program in the Winter term will take first and second semester courses in alternatively delivered formats. The program is unique in Ontario.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Building Renovation Technology Program T148 | George Brown College2023.txt

The text provides a list of courses offered by the college in Building Technologies program across six semesters. Each course is represented by a code and its corresponding name, along with the building or department it belongs to. Here's an organized version of the extracted information:

 Semester 1:
 - MATH 1146: Mathematics for Building Technologies 1
 - BLDG 1082: Construction Layout
 - BLDG 1083: Estimating 1
 - BLDG 1095: Residential Construction Lab 2
 - PORT 1001: Portfolio
 - Plan Interpretation 2

 Semester 2:
 - MATH 1146: Mathematics for Building Technologies 2
 - BLDG 1081: Construction Safety & Rigging
 - BLDG 1020: Interior Millwork and Finishes
 - GSCI 1022: Building Science & Environment

 Semester 3:
 - BLDG 2069: Residential Construction Lab 3
 - BLDG 2074: Planning and Scheduling
 - BLDG 2075: Estimating 2
 - BLDG 1089: Plan Interpretation 2

 Semester 4:
 - COMM 1113: Professional Communications for Building Technologies
 - BLDG 2072: Residential Construction Lab 4
 - BLDG 2008: Associated Trades – Applied Theory and Applications
 - BLDG 2027: Field Placement 1
 - BLDG 2052: Methods of Measurement: Renovation and Redevelopment
 - GNED: General Education Elective

 Semester 5:
 - BLDG 3071: Passive Building 1
 - BLDG 3063: Building Regulations 1 – Zoning
 - BLDG 3067: Residential Design
 - BLDG 3074: Business Management
 - BLDG 3172: Financial Management and Project Accounting

 Semester 6:
 - BLDG 3072: Passive Building 2

 The students may be required to take COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication) before progressing to COMM 1113. However, this course does not count as a course required for graduation and will result in additional charges. There is also a mention of General Education Electives throughout the list.

Context:
The text provides information on a program offered by the college with the following key learning outcomes for the graduate:

1. Develop and use strategies for ongoing professional development.
2. Comply with health and safety practices and procedures.
3. Prepare quotes and ensure work is completed in compliance with contractual obligations, codes, laws, bylaws, standards, and ethical practices.
4. Promote sustainability practices.
5. Facilitate collaboration among tradespersons and project stakeholders.
6. Review and interpret project plans and produce technical sketches and documents.
7. Use technologies to obtain, analyze, organize, and communicate building construction information.
8. Analyze and solve technical problems related to design and implementation of projects using advanced mathematical principles.
9. Select, maintain, and safely use hand tools, portable power tools, and stationary power tools.
10. Complete stages of building construction from site layout to interior and exterior finishes in accordance with blueprint specifications and conservation principles.
11. Evaluate methods employed and the use of equipment and materials in projects.
12. Schedule, coordinate, and monitor project progression using project management strategies.
13. Design and implement business strategies for home building, renovation, and redevelopment enterprises.
14. Apply leadership, supervision, and interpersonal skills to manage projects.

Tuition fees:
- Domestic students: $3,979.00 for the first two semesters
- International students: $17,673.00 for the first two semesters (starting Fall 2023)

Additional costs are subject to change for programs starting in Fall 2023 and at later dates.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Building Renovation Technology Program T148 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
Programs starting in Fall 2023:
- International Students should refer to the International Fees and Related Costs page for fee information.
- This program is approved for OSAP funding for applicants who meet OSAP eligibility criteria.
- Applicants need an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent, with grade 12 English (C or U) and grade 11 math (M or U) or grade 12 (C or U).
- Mature students may take the Admissions Assessment for English and math or consider upgrading to achieve required credits.
- Course exemptions can be obtained through the Transfer Guide.
- Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges, while international students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System.
- For more information, contact the School of Apprenticeship and Skilled Trades at 416-415-5000 ext. 6711 or skilledtrades@georgebrown.ca, or visit the Contact Centre at 416-415-2000 (TTY 1-877-515-5559) or long distance 1-800-265-2002, or contact international recruitment representatives specializing by country of origin.

Year: Fall 2023, Fall 2024, and at later dates
Programs/Fees: International Students - refer to the International Fees and Related Costs page
Financial Assistance: OSAP funding for eligible applicants
Admission Requirements: Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent, grade 12 English (C or U), grade 11 math (M or U) or grade 12 (C or U), mature students may take Admissions Assessment or upgrade credits
Application: Domestic students - Ontario Colleges, International Students - George Brown College Online Application System
Contact Information: School of Apprenticeship and Skilled Trades - 416-415-5000 ext. 6711, skilledtrades@georgebrown.ca; Contact Centre - 416-415-2000 (TTY 1-877-515-5559) or long distance 1-800-265-2002; International recruitment representatives - booking a virtual meeting or submitting an inquiry.
